Background.text: Explosive incident response is divided among three stages:

Pre-Blast_Incidents.text: Refers to an explosive device that has not yet detonated. Pre-blast perimeters should be established based on local protocols, procedures, and guidelines.

Post-Blast_Response.text:
Refers to an incident involving a device that has already exploded. Decisions are based on the destruction caused by the blast (i.e., the amount of explosives used). First, decide where to establish the inner perimeter; perimeter decisions should include the possibility of additional explosive devices.
Triage
can then begin, which may require rescues from a collapsed building.

Continuing_Explosive_Incident.text: These are incidents where a threat from additional explosive devices exists. Responders should seek shelter and safe distance until area is deemed safe for triage and rescue.

Management.text:
According to the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) 472, Section A.4.2.1 (20):
[1]
Evaluate the scene for likely areas where additional devices could be placed.
Visually scan the operating areas (a 360-degree scan from the windshield of a vehicle is preferable).
Avoid touching or moving anything that might conceal an explosive device.
Designate and enforce scene control zones.
